Labor supply behavior of prospective and new mothers
items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Utilizing unique data generated from the National Longitudinal Surveys of Young Women, this paper examines the labor force participation of young mothers in the months immediately preceding and following the birth of the first child. Labor supply behavior at this point in the life cycle is described in greater detail than has hitherto been available. In addition, we analyze the independent effect of several factors of interest on the probability that a young woman will be in the labor force during various intervals surrounding the first birth.</jats:p>

title: A Note on the Estimation of Subjective Rates of Discount from Labour Supply Functions
Research Priorities in Water Supply
items.abstract: <jats:p>What are the most pressing needs and most promising directions for future research on drinking water? The question was the focus of the following discussion held at the 1978 Water Quality Technology Conference in Louisville, Ky. Led by Elroy F. Spitzer, director of the AWWA Research Foundation, the participants were E. Robert Baumann, Marston distinguished professor of engineering and professor of civil engineering at Iowa State University, Ames, Iowa; Paul D. Foley, research coordinator, Ontario Ministry of the Environment, Toronto, Ont.; Garrett P. Sloan, director, Miami Dade Water and Sewer Authority, Miami, Fla.; and Michael J. Taras, project engineer, AWWA Research Foundation, Denver, Colo.</jats:p>

Constant-current supply of 3 ppm stability and resettability; application for a SQUID
items.abstract: <jats:p>We describe a new design for a constant-current supply which is stable and resettable to 3 ppm over a period of one week, even in the presence of ambient temperature changes of several degrees. These characteristics are achieved by utilizing a digital-to-analog converter for providing a changeable, yet extremely stable, reference voltage. Seven full-scale current ranges are available between 0.1 and 100 mA. It is also shown that this constant-current supply is suitable even for use with a SQUID, meeting all of the exacting requirements for such use.</jats:p>

The Southeast Timber Supply: How will it be Affected by Changing Forestry in South America, Canada, and the Northeast?
items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Those responsible for forest investments in the southeastern U.S. are interested in how much and how soon timber produced in other regions—particularly the fast-growth forests in tropical and subtropical areas—will be competitive. The author presents his views on both present and potential effects on the Southeast's timber supply of evolving forestry in South America, Canada, and the northeastern U.S. He concludes that the southern pine region will remain a major supplier of timber and even increase its share of the world market in the immediate future.</jats:p>

title: An ‘H’-type switching mode power supply for d.c. servo motors

Notes and Comments: The Adoption of Metrics by the Water Supply Commission of Victoria, Australia
items.abstract: <jats:p>Prompted by Ken Mains's “The Effect of Metrication on Design,” the author describes the conversion by the State Rivers and Water Supply Commission of Victoria, Australia, to use of metric units for measuring volume and flow rates and for various product specifications. These units have proved practical for water delivery, measurement, and flood‐routing operations.</jats:p>

title: The supply of dental manpower in the United States
items.abstract: <jats:p>This description of the supply of dental services in the United States addresses the number, kind, distribution, and training of dentists and dental auxiliaries, and the organizational factors that affect the production of dental services. Beginning with a brief historical review, the paper gives a general overview of the different types of dental personnel including the dentist, dental hygienist, dental assistant, and laboratory technician. The discussion of these categories of providers includes consideration of manpower planning as it has evolved over the past two decades, National manpower legislation is mentioned first as a reaction to the projected dentist shortage and then in response to the issues of geographic maldistribution and the effects of specialization. The second section of the paper discusses the dynamics of the dental care market. The distribution of the supply of services is identified and related to patterns of utilization and productivity. These factors are considered to be part of the set of dynamic relationships that help explain the current manpower problems of geographic and specialty maldistribution. A concluding section superficially discusses policy implications regarding the potential for increasing supply by: (1) increasing the number of dentists, (2) increasing the numbers and functions of auxiliaries, (3) increasing practice efficiency through group practice, and (4) reducing the restrictions that result from current state dental practice acts.</jats:p>

title: Breast feeding in Cambridge, England: factors affecting the mother's milk supply
items.abstract: <jats:p>Smokers were more likely to have given up breast feeding between 2 weeks and 3 months than non‐smokers but smoking was not associated with any particular weaning reason. Women taking a contraceptive pill during lactation more often experienced a diminution of milk supply than non‐pill‐takers.</jats:p><jats:p>Sustained lactation benefits the mother since those who were still breast feeding were less likely to suffer from depression or fatigue at 3 months, and were more likely to have lost weight. The early introduction of solids was less frequent among infants being breast fed at 3 months.</jats:p>

Avian cerebral blood flow: influence of the Bohr effect on oxygen supply
container-title: American Journal of Physiology-Heart and Circulatory Physiology
items.abstract: <jats:p> To clarify the problems of altitude tolerance in birds, we studied the combined effect of hypocapnia and hypoxia on cerebral blood flow (CBF) in ducks. CBF was measured by the xenon clearance method. Normocapnic hypoxia causes CBF to increase when the arterial O2 tension (PaO2) falls below 60--70 mmHg. Hypocapnic hypoxia significantly shifts the blood flow curve so that blood flow does not increase until a lower PaO2 (50--60 mmHg) is reached. This gives the appearance that hypocapnia suppresses the hypoxia-induced increase in CBF. However, due to the Bohr effect, the hypocapnic blood contains significantly more O2 than does the normocapnic blood at the same PaO2. Therefore, when CBF is expressed as a function of O2 content, rather than PO2, CBF in the hypocapnic group does not differ significantly from the CBF in the normocapnic group. We interpret this to mean that because of the significantly greater oxygen content of the hypocapnic blood at a given PaO2, the degree of hypoxia experienced by these brains is not as severe as that experienced by the normocapnic brains. </jats:p>

title: Uncertainties plague ethylene industry
Trace nutrients.
items.abstract: <jats:p>1. Intakes of magnesium, copper, zinc, vitamin B<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>, vitamin B<jats:sub>12</jats:sub> and folic acid in Britain were calculated by applying the values selected for the 4th edition of <jats:italic>McCance and Widdowson's The Composition of Foods</jats:italic> (Paul & Southgate, 1978) to the amounts of food recorded in the National Food Survey made during 1976 (Ministry of Agiculture, Fisheries and Food, 1977).</jats:p><jats:p>2. National average intakes were (/person per d): Mg 249 mg, Cu 1.51 mg, Zn 9.1 mg, vitamin B<jats:sub>6</jats:sub> 1.36 mg, vitamin B<jats:sub>12</jats:sub> 6.6 μg, free folic acid 105 μg and total folic acid 190 μg. Corresponding intakes (/person) in families with four or more children were 10–20% lower.</jats:p><jats:p>3. A comparison of intakes with those recommended in Canada (Department of National Health and Welfare, 1976) and the USA (National Research Council, 1974) or by WHO (1973) indicated that for folic acid average values were particulary low, and only for vitamin B<jats:sub>12</jats:sub> were the recommendations significantly exceeded.</jats:p><jats:p>4. Contributions from alcoholic drinks and confectionery were also calculated and found, on average, to be significant for Cu, vitamin B<jats:sub>12</jats:sub> and folic acid.</jats:p><jats:p>5. The losses of B-vitamins which might occur on cooking are discussed.</jats:p>
